div1.p: Connor discusses the yellow fever work in El Salvador.

div1.head: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, December 26, 1924
div1.opener:
Copy.
6a. Seccion de la
Direccion General de Sanidad:
Sub-Seccion Especial de Lucha
y Control Contra el Aedes
Aegypti
Rep. de el Salvador C.A.
San Salvador, Salvador
December 26, 1924.
Sir:
div1.p:
Subject - Plan of Campaign to Control Yellow Fever
in the Republic of El Salvador.

The yellow fever infection has appeared at varying intervals as an
epidemic in El Salvador. The recent outbreak was first recognized on June
5th., and the epidemic appears to have been controlled by the third week of
October since when no case of the infection has been found or reported.
During the epidemic 80 cases with 27 deaths were reported from three cities.
The reporting system in the country is regarded as average.

Unquestionably there were cases of yellow fever present before the
formal announcement. The failure of knowledge of these earlier cases may be
laid to the fact that many patients ill with very mild attack do not call for
the services of a physician and in the absence of an efficient house inspections
service the Health Authorities must remain in ignorance of the presence of the
disease until the infection acquires a virulence calling for the physicians
aid. I subscribe to the above rather than to the thought that this can and
does exist in a community in an unrecognizable form.

It is not difficult to understand the reluctance sometimes exhibited
by physicians in refraining to announce early suspicious cases of yellow fever
because of the upset produced in the community by such announcement. With a
more complete knowledge of the value of the Noguchi vaccine it may develop that
it can be applied to supersede the present quarantine restrictions, if so, one
would expect earlier announcements of suspicious cases of yellow fever.

The present co-operative campaign to control yellow fever in Salvador
was entered upon between Direccion General de Sanidad and the International
Health as of October 1, 1924. The basis of work is the reduction of the aedes
aegypti by attacking the insect in its aquatic stage. In brief, anti-larvae
measures.

Former campaigns had been planned and conducted with the fish playing
a leading role as larvae consumers. The present campaign was first projected
with fish as an important ally but once upon the ground this measure was
abandoned in favor of the “System of fines” as developed by the National Health
Department and from which very satisfactory results are flowing. This system
is being continued without causing any hardship to the people.

It is not the intention to convey the impression that fish are not
used, to the contrary, we recommend their efficiency to people who depend upon
wells or stow the domestic water supply in open concrete tanks, barrels and
similar receptacles and who prefer fish, to practicing the measures prescribed
by the Service for mosquito proofing water receptacles, in which case the
people are obligated to secure the fish for their own account.

The Anti-Aedes aegypti service aims to secure the reduction of this
mosquito through the co-operation of the people who are requested to empty
and clean at least once each week all receptacles used in and near the home
for stowing the domestic water supply the only exceptions being indoor tanks
which must be properly covered and shallow wells for which fish are recommended.
For failure to co-operate the Service imposes a fine of two colones for the
first remission with increasing penalties for persistent infractions. Each
home is visited by an Inspector who notes if the instructions are being carried
out.

The usual method followed in assigning area to an Inspector is to
allocate to each man a sector based on a daily inspection of between 50 and 75
- 3 -
homes the entire area to be completed in six consecutive days. In some instances
the Inspector is accompanied by an assistant as is necessary when oil is
sprayed in a general anti-mosquito service. In strictly anti-aedes aegypti
work oil plays no part, and its use is misleading.

The inspection system in Salvador has been modified and we are now
practicing an improved “group plan” and designated as “Brigadas Volantes” or
“Ambulantes”, we have two such Brigadas, each comprising six inspectors and
a Supervisor. The Brigadas Volantes are on a schedule to visit all large
centers of population based on the findings of our mosquito survey, at intervals
of about three weeks. No additional anti-larvae measures are applied in the
centers during the interval of visits by the Brigadas. For one week each month
both Brigadas are assembled in San Salvador for inspections in this city.

Our preliminary mosquito survey in Salvador clearly proves that all
communities have not as yet been invaded by the aedes aegypti notwithstanding
that some of the towns and villages inspected have a population of two and three
thousand people but the “aegypti free” towns have no permanent water containers,
that is to say, that the people have only small earthenware containers for
stowing water which are refilled daily from a nearby river or stream.

In communities where public pilas serve the people we find that the
aegypti are established and that people carry the larvae from the pilas to
their homes where they continue development. With the mosquito proofing of
the pila by emptying the pila and scrubbing the inside surface to remove eggs
we eliminate it as a permanent breeding place and this process repeated for a
time should extinguish the species in such communities.

The development of the Brigada Volante is a natural result of the
thought that there is little, if anything, to be gained, by continuing intensive
work regularly in a city when the house index has been lowered to below 5% and
maintained there for a reasonable time. I think that we are justified in assuming
- 4 -
that the rate of rise in the house index is a relatively slow process during
the dry season and this factor alone permits of the temporary withdrawal of
inspectors from an “intensive area” and utilizing them for extensive work. We
are hoping to secure accurate data on the rate of rise in the house index from
this procedure.
The disposition of the Brigadas is as follows:

The Republic of El Salvador is divided into two sectors, East and West,
one brigada is assigned to each sector with a schedule of centers to be
inspected. All municipalities here have been planned on the block or manzana
system, that is, the streets are at right angles and parallel to each other, a
row of manzanas is selected and each inspector is given a block to inspect and
upon finishing his detail he passes to another manzana designated by the supervisor
and this continues until the row of manzanas has been inspected when the group
repeats the process in another column of blocks. It will be noted that the
inspector is never more than six blocks away from the Supervisor and this factor
permits easy and complete check on the work of the individual inspector and
should develop increased efficiency. With this system we have reduced our personnel
from 60 to 25.

The Central office notifies the local authorities of the expected
arrival of the Brigadas and requests for them all aid possible. This
assistance takes the form of providing the men with a place to sleep and a
civil guard to accompany to the group while at work, the guard is a guarantee
to the public that the inspectors are authorized to make the visit. The
assistance from the local authorities is most willingly given.

Later I will report in detail on the rate of rise in the house index
as observed during the present dry season. The accompanying views will show
the average water container in use in Salvador.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, (Signed) M.E. Connor International Health Board
61 Broadway, New York, N.Y.
